try using a local variable in the function.Ô_ It might not be the best way to try assigning values inside of the return statement. If it was shorter, it might be easier.Ô_ Like we did in class, you can assign a local variable-- then when you return the value it might look likereturn hours_floatwhere hours_float is a local variable defined just within your function.Hope i didn't spoil anything!
for this in shell:time_to_utc(-1.5, 22.0)I had 23.5 -- because I thought we were supposed to convert it to base 10 (and often decimal point)I don't know if that's correct.

however, 23.5 is what I had for your statement above, and I got everything correct (41/41) in my assignment program...Ô_Ô_ so I guess it's right.Ô_ I think you're using base 60 for the clock (and instead using minutes) instead of representing that as a fractional (decimal) amount, which is base-10.30 mins = 0.5 hours etc.

The professors said they were going to test with partial (decimal) offsets. There are some timecodes that are -1.5 and such. Depending on where in the world they are located. They said they are going to test all possibles, and will test for that-- they stated they PURPOSELY did NOT include those (fractional) offsets with our examples so that they could check for it in grading. If you don't get the right answer for a partial offset, your program could be partially incorrect. I'd highly suggest checking for it!This was my result (I'm guessing it is correct) -- you can check yours:>>> time_to_utc(-1.5, 22.0)Ô_Ô_Ô_ 23.50

look at the steps below that...Ô_ notice the moduloÔ_ % Ô_ operator. Ô_ It can be used to get the remainder from something.Ô_ It can be used, in one way, to get the result you want.Also note what they say about the time:there's 3600 seconds in an hour. Ô_ You can use that info to calculate it.Ô_ You should be able to test some data, and expect a certain result.Don't forget you need to callÔ_ to_24_hour_clock and put your result into that when you get done, for your "get_hours" function...---------========--------Look at the steps they told you about the operands of % and //Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_ (they will be used in this step).About the first part of step 5 (take the first step first!)--Ô_ :Ô_Ô_ - if there are 3800 seconds,Ô_ that means there's 1 hour, 3 minutes and 20 seconds....because if you take the number of seconds in an hour away from 3800, you're left with 200.Ô_ Get the minutes and it's 3 whole minutes, with a remainder of 20 seconds....Ô_ Read the steps carefully,Ô_ is the best advice I could give---Ô_ don't overthink it!Ô_ It's not THAT hard.....Ô_ go back and read step 5 from the beginning..Ô_ it might help to go back and look at what you did for earlier steps, maybe?

You should be able to run the examples they gave in our assignment one link: http://spark-public.s3.amazonaws.com/programming1/a1/a1.html Step 5 test examples (included in link-page):
            For example:
        
            >>> get_hours(3800)
    1
    >>> get_minutes(3800)
    3
    >>> get_seconds(3800)
    20
            
So you know you've got the right result if you come up with those answers.Ô_ It's not too hard. Just the even number of hours, even number of minutes, and even number of seconds (even, meaning only focus on that one part at a time-- you can do the hours, seconds, and minutes independently of each other-- you'd know how many extra seconds you had if you were given thousands of seconds--- as well as the minutes, and the hours by using the same principle).Ô_ Only focus on one thing at a time--- hours, then minutes, then seconds.

Latif-Ô_ maybe try using local variables inside your functions?Ô_ Remember those are variables that are only relevant INSIDE the function. Once you call the return statement, they clear their value.Ô_ It can make working with operands much easier, and might make it less confusing instead of trying to cram everything into one step.Ô_ Just logically step thorough the parts one step at a time, before trying to move on to the other parts in your program.Ô_ It makes it easier to assign a value to a local variable, then you can pass that variable in the return.Ô_ It makes it less likely that you confuse something, and thus makes it easier to track down any possible errors on one's program.for example, perhaps this might be a technique that you could use?Ô_ Where parameter_variable is something that maybe is called in your function, or maybe is an argument-- depending on the use....Ô_ Here's a simple example of using a local variable, it might make things easier for you, perhaps?Ô_ You could insert something like this in your function, it might make it easier to split apart the steps so you didn't get hung up on any one part... a = 1 + parameter_variableb = get_something(a)Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_ Ô_ Ô_ Ô_ <--- function call to get_something with the value of 'a' in itreturn b

Teresa--Ô_ I think we just call the "to_24_hour_clock" AFTER we've gotten our result from our function... that is our "time_to_utc" will have that call after it has calculated the time FROM the UTC and what that is... without that function call you are likely to end up with negative time, which cannot occur.You can check all your example from what was given to kinda look for the pattern.Ô_ I had to do an operational type command, because of the fact that there is NO such thing as Negative time!!!Ô_ So therefore I had to have a conditional statement that prevented any negative numbers or 0 from messing up my arguments.Here's a link on how to do Logical statements, you might find that you need to have a certain case if a number is negative-- and a certain case if a number is 0.Ô_ Because you can't use certain commands with 0, especially some operands like %, /, //Ô_Ô_Ô_ So I made a special case to deal with everything EXCEPT for 0.Ô_ I also turned any negative numbers into a positive number.Ô_ If you remember we had a command to do this--Ô_Ô_ absÔ_ (absolute number)Ex.>>>abs(-3.5)Ô_3.5Hope it helps....Ô_Ô_ Here's a link you might find useful.Ô_ There's more than one way to skin a cat!Ô_ ;-)http://www.tutorialspoint.com/python/logical_operators_example.htm

Oh to answer your question,Ô_ the call to_24_hour_clock needs to occur somewhere in your return statement, perhaps?Ô_ Otherwise you could end up with a number MUCH higher than 24 hours in a day!Ô_ Remember that your call to_24_hour_clock turns it into a "real" 24 hour time...Ô_Ô_ You might end up with some answers giving you 35 hours or something, unless you use a that before or in the return call.I created a couple of local variables,Ô_ and also made one called a- which I made 0,Ô_ and made sure that time was <> 0.Ô_ Otherwise I made sure I had an absolute time amount, and not a negative time... hope it helps guys!If time was negative I did one thing... If time was 0, I did another.Ô_ Incidentally time_to_utc, and time_from_utc were almost EXACLY the same... I was able to cut and paste almost all of it.

Check out my above comment, it might help you out... also check out this page---Ô_ I had to make conditional arguments....Ô_ In one case,Ô_ if time = 0Ô_ I did one thing.In another, if time was negative, I made it positive.Ô_Ô_ Then I put that value into a local variable called new_time_var -- I used this to store the value from a pattern I noticed.Ô_ http://www.tutorialspoint.com/python/logical_operators_example.htm Case 1 (timeÔ_ is midnight?):You might have to do something if time happens to be "0".. which is obviously not the case.Case 2Ô_ (time is negative):Ô_ you can use something like absolute command to convert this to a positive number, since time is not negative.Then convert that time to regular 24-hour format (not over!) with to_24_hour_clockREMEMBER-- there is always more than one way to skin a cat!!Ô_ ;-)

Latif -- why do you have 2 modulos, and 2 returns, in your get_minutes??Ô_ You ALMOST have it right... I think if you focus on 3600 seconds in an hour, instead of having to % by 36 then // 10.You might put the value of get_minutes into a local variable that only runs inside the function like so (I'm going by what you used in your statement, I'm not saying if that's right or not-- I think there's an easier way to represent that amount, but I'm showing you this for your benefit-- and since you already had it typed....Ô_ )You had 2 return statments in your get_minutes function... obviously once the first one is called, the 2nd one won't be called.Ô_ So to do what you're trying to do, you could use a local (temporary) variable that would represent a statement or calculation or variable into a temporary variable, then you can use that to call another function if you like!temp_var = (seconds%3600)//60then try calling function after that using "temp_var" or whatever name you pick for the local variable...THEN return what you get back from function in the return call.

You can't have 60 seconds in time!Ô_ It would then go to 1 min!Ô_ So you have to make sure seconds does not exceed 59!3600 seconds in an hour....Ô_ so 3800 - 3600 = 200 seconds200 secondsÔ_ = 3 whole minutes WITH= 20 seconds left!!!minutes is another step down from hours,Ô_ 60 seconds in a minute, 60 seconds in an hour!Ô_ So if you simply get the hour amount (by 3600), that does not YET give you the number of minutes... it takes an additional statement...

Check this out... I found out that I had left 2 characters out that gave me about 7 errors.... you can assume that any mistake will be compounded whenever they run the program against it. See what failed and then try to do that....Ô_ Remember everything needs to be in exactly EVEN number amounts for hours, mins, seconds!Ô_ Read this forum on how to make sense of the grading:https://class.coursera.org/programming1-002/forum/thread?thread_id=1027

See if you can test your get_hours, get_minutes, and get_seconds with this:    >>> get_hours(3800)
    1
    >>> get_minutes(3800)
    3
    >>> get_seconds(3800)
    20

Great to hear!Ô_ My years of programming classes from my computer programming major are coming back!Ô_ I got hung up on the easiest stuff, but found the difficult things easiest.Ô_Ô_ I had actually done this program backwards before realizing we had instructions... go figure....Ô_Ô_ I started with step 5 or 6.

Hint:Ô_ One statement of mine looked like this:if not (time and 0):Ô_Ô_ condition if (time and 0):Ô_Ô_ abs(time)Though as was stated I'm not sure abs was necessary.Ô_ I solved it in about 6 steps....Ô_ I don't think we actually have covered that.. .though I'm in so many programming classes I can't keep straight what we've learned in what class. Apparently there is another way to do this without IF statments.... so that would be best to do, since we don't have IF statements yet... sorry I was confused about what class I was in...it is midnight, if it's zero-- and then there's often mins or seconds left!Ô_ So if you notice the examples given work differently if time = 0, so you have to make a case for that.then don't forget to call to_24_hour_clock-- because it's not 35 o'clock anywhere!Ô_ as last statement, before return.since you can't have 35 o'clockÔ_ you have to convert to 24 hour clock...Ô_ you also can't have a NEGATIVE clock time, except when you're referring to how much extra time you have (NOT!)Ô_ you spent it all working on this assignment....Sorry, passes for humor...

See if you can get any of these results that are included with our code that included:Ô_Ô_Ô_ >>> time_from_utc(+0, 12.0)Ô_Ô_Ô_ 12.0Ô_Ô_Ô_ >>> time_from_utc(+1, 12.0)Ô_Ô_Ô_ 13.0Ô_Ô_Ô_ >>> time_from_utc(-1, 12.0)Ô_Ô_Ô_ 11.0Ô_Ô_Ô_ >>> time_from_utc(+6, 6.0)Ô_Ô_Ô_ 12.0Ô_Ô_Ô_ >>> time_from_utc(-7, 6.0)Ô_Ô_Ô_ 23.0Ô_Ô_Ô_ >>> time_from_utc(-1, 0.0)Ô_Ô_Ô_ 23.0Ô_Ô_Ô_ >>> time_from_utc(-1, 23.0)Ô_Ô_Ô_ 22.0Ô_Ô_Ô_ >>> time_from_utc(+1, 23.0)Ô_Ô_Ô_ 0.0the first parameter is the UTC code (where the time zone is!),Ô_ the 2nd is what time it is there... so you can figure out the pattern as such:-1 UTC, and it's 23:00 so that means it's really UTC (now) 22:00Ô_ -- since we're just one 1 hr off.Ô_ You don't go above 24 for any time-- and time can not be negative.

column8: The problem summary: Assignment 2 step 5 (ii) the two tests for get_complementary_sequence(str) produce a 'FAILURE' when marked unless you allow lowercase (a, t, c and g). And as we know from step 3 is_valid_sequence(str) "A string is not a valid DNA sequence if it contains lowercase letters".I had to change my code to allow 'atcg' as well as 'ATCG', which feels a bit, umm...cheat-y.>>>get_complementary_sequence('AT') + ' Pete'Steps to reproduce:Write code that only allows capital letters, like your told to in step 3, then submit your code to the 'less-pedantic-than-me' marking machine.Screenshot:

My code worked in IDLE but I got 22/24 on first submission. I re-wrote bits and checked get_complementary_sequence(str), like a hundred times (about 10 really) in IDLE and it still worked. I sub'd again and still got 22/24. Then I just changed the code to allow lowercase 'actg' and ka-pow...full marks.I really just posted so that anyone else stuck like that would know what to do.

I think I've been misunderstood. I was just trying to help anyone else with the same problem.My original code worked perfectly in IDLE, but I didn't get full marks until (i.e. I now have 24/24 so no longer care much) I allowed lowercase 'atcg'.That's all, if it didn't happen to you then I must be wrong about the auto-marking and this thread is a waste of everyone's time. Sorry about that. Good luck with the rest of the course everyone.

If you do define a function in the shell (that will be gone as soon as you close it), when you are done writing the body of the function press Enter until the prompt >>> appears on the left side of theÔ_current line. [Enter shoul be pressed twice; if you press it only once, the shell is waiting for you to enter another line in the function body]
You don't need to do anything about the precondition. The precondition means you can assume that the input meets that precondition, and don't need to check for it.

Yes, you can use. I have submitted with doctest and it worked. The grader seems to be using unittest for checking our work. It just imports the module, and the doctest part never executes. Code for that below:if __name__ == '__main__':
    import doctest
    doctest.testmod()Just put this at the end of the (a1.py) file.If all the tests included in the docstring work (exactly as in the docstring), there will be no output.

column8: 1. You don't need the len(s1) at the end.2. That's going to begin looking at the spot where it finds the first occurrence of s2 - and basically just find the same one again, so it says the second occurrence of s2 is at the same place as the first (and therefore that there are always two of them, even when there actually is only one.). Ô_You want it to start looking AFTER that spot.Hope that helped and wasn't confusing! :P

Hi
Linda,

What
you include in the return statement is the expression that you want to return.

For
example, let's make a function called "area" which takes base
length and height and heightÔ_of a triangularÔ_and returns the area

Here's
the code:def area(base_length, height):
    return base_length * height /2
And here's an example of running this code>>> area(5,6)15.0In the example that you gave, the function takes a name of a city and returns the temperature. So the return statements should include the expression that gives the temperature. You don't need to include the parameters or any information that isn't needed for the calculation. For example, in theÔ_is_passing_grade that you asked about the return statement is 'pass' or 'fail' because that's what we need to return and it doesn't include the grade.I hope that helped...

Here's the output I got when executing the function:>>> is_passing_grade(40)'fail'>>> is_passing_grade(67)'pass'Just to check: after you inserted the code in IDLE, did you run the module (by pressing F5 or choosing Run->Run Module)?In your return statement you shouldn't includeÔ_temperature('city') but an expression that calculates the temperature using the argument: city.

Since you can use convert_to_minutes (id1)Ô_andÔ_convert_to_seconds (id2)Ô_anywhere in the
program (even within another function) those functions should be considered as
global.

However, a function that is declared within another function
is considered as local to the function within which it is declared so you can't
use it outside this function.Try this with the Visualizer:

Ô_def func1(a):
    def func2(b):
        return b**2
    return a*3+func2(a)

column8:
Hi,

You
don_ã_t need to download anything for this exercise. assignment.py and
question.py are names of hypothetical files.

In
order to answer the question, suppose that you have a file that contains some
code in Python which is called assignment.py. From this file you need to call
functions from another hypothetical file, called question.py. 

How
do you do that?And regrading your second questions - the weekly exercises are inÔ_https://class.coursera.org/programming1-002/quiz/index?quiz_type=homeworkÔ_while the Assignments (every other week) are inÔ_https://class.coursera.org/programming1-002/assignment/index.You don't need the book in order to complete them.

Hi James, in this assignment we're not required to address this issue (I
submitted the assignment without taking care of the case of the inputs and got
a perfect score). Ô_
You're right! What I meant in my reply to James is that you don't have to check for this or do anything that is connected to upper/lower case.

Don't worry about this... If for example you need to check if chr is "G" the expression is chr=="G" (so we won't accept "g" as a valid character). Other than that you don't have to take care of this issue. I re-checked the assignment that I submitted and saw that I didn't use any function/method that dealt with the upper/lower case issue.

I think that your code and mine work as designed: in "my"Ô_chr=="G" Ô_example, if chr is "g", this expression will return False as it should. So as the spec says "A string is not a valid DNA sequence if it contains lowercase letters". If I say that I want to make sure that chr is "G", why should I care if Ô_chr is "g" (the lowercase of "G") or "X"? In both cases the expression will return False as it should...

In the example mentioned on the template for a2.pycontains_sequence('ATCGGC', 'GG')the sequence GG is inÔ_ATCGGC but not at the beginning of the string (for example "ATC") or at the end (for example, "GC"). I assume, based on the names of the tests that you mentioned, that you didn't check those two cases.Try to run:contains_sequence('ATCGGC', 'ATC')contains_sequence('ATCGGC', 'GC')and see if you get True for those cases

Yes!
Define two strings one for the nucleotide and one for complement
and make sure that the x-th character of complement is the complement of
the x-th character of nucleotide.

Imagine a code where A is replaced by Z, B is replaced by Y, etc.

So 

If original
is "ABCDE_ã_.Z", the code is "ZYXWV_ã_.A".

Apply
similar logic to nucleotide and complement

Ô_

And
then think of an expression you should include in your return statement, that
looks for the place of a certain chr in nucleotide and return the chr in
complement with the same place.

column8: Do you have a return statement?

As always when dealing with indexing/slicing using [a:b] notation, we're looking for all the characters from the a-th position to the b-th (not including the b-th position), so [i:i+1] is the i-th position to the i+1 -th position, but excluding the i+1 - th position, so it practically means only the character in the i-th position, so to answer your question:Ô_s[i:i + 1] is just like s[i]. Try for example,Ô_'abcABCabcABC'[5] and see that it's equal toÔ_'abcABCabcABC'[5:6].

column8: Hi Sajjad;I am an Electronic Engineer - doing hard core circuit design (photon counting devices, lasers, solar / wind switching power supplies and the like).If you do Engineering rather than paperwork, you will definitely need some (any) programming language to solve various "quick and dirty" real life problems. - usually those that are a bit more than a simple calculator can handle.I use several different languages, from assemblers to C++, but am finding that Python is the all around best language to use as a "I need it quick" problem solver.In sort, it should become part of your engineering toolbox, just like a calculator and a DVM.Good luck.

(Learned a lot as well)Good luck.

column8: "is" instead of '==' was also the cause of my late night yesterday, where I kept trying to change my get_complementary_sequence code to pass (mentioned the assertionerror as well). However, when reusing the get_complement function in the get_complementary_sequence code it failed autograde (even though the results in the shell were correct). Lesson of the day..... 'is' is not ==! If it weren't for the forums I would never have found out, most likely. :)

column8: Fred, you've asked a lot of questions here, so it's a little hard to know how to start answering them, but I'll try to go through one by one (also: I'm a student, not a lecturer, so no guarantees I'm doing things the right or the best way!).First of all: you submit assignments by going to the assignments link on the main screen, choosing the assignment you're submitting, then clicking the 'submit' button to upload your .py file.Second: The visualiser is located on the internet here:Ô_http://www.pythontutor.com/visualize.htmlThree and four: Once you have Idle open, select File -> New Window to open a new window to edit it, or use File -> Open to open an existing file (such as a1.py if you're working on your first assignment). You can resize the windows by grabbing the edges of it and moving it to where you need it. If you resize the shell and the editor to both be about half the size of your screen, then you can place them side by side. If you have the windows maximised (which means you won't be able to grab the edges) then just double click in the title bar at the top to minimise them so you can grab the edges.Hope that helps!

When you attempt a homework again, all the answers will be cleared out, but you can see what you answered before by clicking on the "Show Previous Attempts" several lines under the "Attempt Homework" button. Ô_From that page you can review all of the answers for your previous attempts. Ô_You can open this in a separate window and refer back as you are doing the exercise.Watch out, though. Ô_Do not copy directly from the previous answers without reading! Ô_At the very least the choices will appear in random order. Ô_For some classes, the questions change when you re-attempt. Ô_This can be anything from giving you different data to use in a calculation to giving you an entirely different question. Ô_

I understand the definition and what recursion does, but I can't quite understand how (or WHY!) it works.In a book I'm currently reading, as an example of how recursion works, a simple Fibonacci program is provided. def fib(n):    if n == 0:        return 0    elif n == 1:        return 1    else:        return fib(n-1) + fib(n-2)I can't understand why this works, though. If n is not 0 or 1, then fib is just called again with a different value for n. HOW does this computes any kind of value? Another problem I don't quite understand is this one...The greatest common divisor (GCD) of a and b is the largest number that dividesboth of them with no remainder. One way to ‚‘Ånd the GCD of two numbers is Euclid_ã_s algorithm, which is based on the observation that if r is the remainder when a is divided by b, then gcd(a, b) = gcd(b, r). As a base case, we canuse gcd(a, 0) = a.Write a function called gcd that takes parameters a and b and returns their greatest common divisor.I was able to solve the problem with:def gcd(a,b):Ô_Ô_Ô_ if b == 0:Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_ return aÔ_Ô_Ô_ elif a % b == 0:Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_ return bÔ_Ô_Ô_ remainder = a % bÔ_Ô_Ô_ return gcd(b, remainder)This seems to work fine, but I don't understand why. Even though I wrote this program on my own, I'm not quite sure why/how it works.Can someone please shine some light on this for me?

column8: That is merely a math question. When you divide 100/3, you get 33, 333333... Now, you need to understand that if you want to apply this "infinite" floating number to something that is either practical or quantifiable you need to round the number in order to do that. Note that when you divide 1 by 3 (0.3) and then you multiply this result by three, you should have the initial unit, but you don't, you now get 0.9 and not 1. The way to solve this is by rounding by the decimal points.I'm sorry to disagree with my friends above, they are right on their explanation but, on my point of view, this is not an error. It's a solution computer makes due to this math curiosity. However, I'm just really subscribing what they are saying.Hope I've make it explicit to you.

Here's my version!! :)def FizzBuzz(num):
	'''(int)-> str
	Given a number num, print de number from 1 to num, replacing 3 multiples for Fizz! , 5 multiples for Buzz! and multiples of 15 for FizzBuzz!.

    Fizzbuzz(99)
    1! 2! Fizz! 4! Buzz! Fizz! 7! 8! Fizz! Buzz! 11!
    Fizz! 13! 14! FizzBuzz! 16! 17! Fizz! 19! Buzz!
    Fizz! 22! 23! Fizz! Buzz! 26! Fizz! 28! 29!
    FizzBuzz! 31! 32! Fizz! 34! Buzz! Fizz! 37! 38!
    Fizz! Buzz! 41! Fizz! 43! 44! FizzBuzz! 46! 47!
    Fizz! 49! Buzz! Fizz! 52! 53! Fizz! Buzz! 56! Fizz!
    58! 59! FizzBuzz! 61! 62! Fizz! 64! Buzz! Fizz! 67!
    68! Fizz! Buzz! 71! Fizz! 73! 74! FizzBuzz! 76! 77!
    Fizz! 79! Buzz! Fizz! 82! 83! Fizz! Buzz! 86! Fizz!
    88! 89! FizzBuzz! 91! 92! Fizz! 94! Buzz! Fizz! 97!
    98! Fizz!
    '''
	for num in range (1, num+1):
		if num%3==0 and num%5==0:
			print ('FizzBuzz!')
		elif num%3==0:
			print ('Fizz!')
		elif num%5==0:
			print ('Buzz!')
		else:
			print (str(num)+'!')My only problem is how not to add a line jump after each number :P
Great, thanks!! :)

>>> get_complement('AGGCT')Ô_ Ô_ 'TCCGA'a complement if you read the assignment domain:DNA has 2 strands in a double helix. The nucleotides in one strand are bonded to the nucleotides in the other strand. A and T can be bonded together, and thusÔ_complementÔ_each other; similarly, C and G are complements of each other.

column8:
Remember you are defining the function at this point so you can use it later. You are just trying to write a return statement that returns a value that matches your type contract. In your example above you are trying to call the function within the function you are defining. Simply return the value of the math you are doing. Once you do that Save the file and hit f5 or Run->Run Module from the menu. This will then run your "a1.py" file and load in functions you are working on.You can then CALL the function you just made. The examples above are meant to be used at this point not as an example of what the body of the function should be. Just think of it this way... when something has the three >>> arrows that means you are RUNNING / USING your functions, whereas, when you are editing things in the a1.py you are DEFINING the functions so they can be RUN / CALLED from the python shell.Hope this helps connect the dots. So once you Save your a1.py file and Run->Run Module (f5) you will copy and paste the EXAMPLES they provided to TEST out whether you are returning the correct value. >>> seconds_difference(1800.0, 3600.0)
1800.0If you get the wrong value don't worry, just think about your math and re-read the description to see if you have your math backward or what not.Ô_

In this problem the seconds parameter that is being passed does not have an upper value (i.e. 59). Ô_The returned value after the computation is done should be a value between 0 and 59. Ô_As you stated...once you hit 12:01 then you go beyond 59. Ô_For instance, 5 minutes after midnight would be 300 seconds. Ô_Your formula within the function needs to break the total number of seconds down into hours, minutes and seconds. Ô_When the seconds exceeds 59, minutes are incremented...when the minutes exceed 59, hours are incremented. Ô_It takes a little bit to backwards engineer the seconds. Ô_

Larry,Ô_ I viewed this problem in the same way that Excel treats days...Excel uses a serial number to represent a date and establishes a starting point at Jan 1, 1900. Ô_To compute the difference between days is then just simple math. Ô_In this problem the data is seconds instead of say days. Ô_To me, the midnight specification is just the point that was decided upon to be zero hour. Ô_Knowing the number of seconds from that point I can compute how many seconds, minutes, hours even days, weeks months, etc have elapsed. Ô_You're right...the problem can be solved using just simple division...and by combining the different functions you can take some large number of seconds and break it down to the hours, minutes and seconds. Ô_I'm just here to broaden personal skills...quite sure there are many ways to skin this cat.

well, say you have a function that calculates the square of a number:def square(num):
    return num ** 2
and now you want to calculate the half of a square of a number. You can either do it like this:def half_square(num):
    return (num ** 2) / 2but this is redundant as you already defined a function which calculates the square of a number.But you can use this function (you've already defined) inside your new function, but make sure that you use the values provided by the function you're about to write(ie. parameters or variables defined in the function body):def half_square(num):
    return square(num) / 2It's more or less the same like using a built-in function inside a self-defined function.

column2: Lectures / Week 2 / Input/Output and str Formatting
column8: Hi,-The purpose of print (or any derivative) is to output the evaluated expression to the output. In IDLEs case: the console or cli or whatever you want to call it.-The purpose of return is to return the evaluated expression to the caller. Consider,def randomfunc(x): Ô_// this function will return the provided number (x) + 1Ô_ Ô_ return x+1returnvalue = randomfunc(2) //This would mean returnvalue points to 3. We haven't seen 3 yet thoughprint(returnvalue) // This will display 3 in the console.In essence, return will provide the evaluated expression to the caller so it can continue it's function. It may take many function calls and return values before the end user even sees it (through use of print)
column13: I can't get it, about print and return

column2: Lectures / Week 2 / Input/Output and str Formatting
column8:
As Janine said, as soon as a function hits a return statement, it will evaluate the expression and return it to the caller. No statements will be processed after that. So, just need to reorder:def sum2(num1, num2):
    print('hello')
    return num1 + num2
    print('goodbye') #Note that this will never be called because it's unreachable due to the return statement

result = sum2(1,3)
print(result)

column8: Hello Harmony. First of all, calm down. Im over 7 years experienced programmer and I had had a lot of problems like this.My first advice is (and you know it): read carefully. REALLY carefully. Then try to not get angry with it. Im here too because I dont understand it.Well, the problem, just like the other mate points out, is RECURSION. He explained it well. Recursion is like asking oneself for the same task until is done. You dont need it know, ok?Second advice and a little history of myself. When you really dont get it, you paste and re-paste code and re-work, ITS TIME to clean up, just start again. Follow the Fuction Design Recipe and do it slow, remember that you are a begginer.One day I was on a great deadline with an AVL tree(advanced topic) and I just dont get it. At 3 AM, tired as hell, I deleted all my code and start again. Slowly, I maked it 2 hours late on the first try.Calm down and it would Ô_go fine.Now the problem:You need the difference between time2 and time1 right? So what is that? What is the difference between something and something? its - right?What about time2 - time1? Try to return it.Then save you file(you are working on a1.py right?) and press F5 to run it.The IDLE shell is going to say "Restart" and then you can type "seconds_difference(1800.0, 3600.0)". Ô_Try it.Ô_I hope I help you and all who read me.

I had the same doubt as Anonymous, and at first I understood this sentence "opposite": as all examples are "full" hours, I thought I should use examples like one-and-half hour for time, offset being always the whole number.

But according to the note in Wikipedia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_zone):Most of the time zones on land are offset from Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) by a whole number of hours (UTC__ê12 to UTC+14), but a few are offset by 30 or 45 minutes.
You're right. Time zones are still more "on the hour" that the time itself!Well, I stopped worrying about it, as my code fortunately works for both offset and time being not the whole number.

In the video there is a demonstration of creating list1 and then setting list2=list1. The video then shows list1 being modified and list2 having the same modification.After some experimentation I figured out the list.copy() method results in a "shallow" copy of a list that appears to be disentangled from the original list, so changes to the original list are not reflected in the copy.I guess my question is why the default would be that setting two lists equal to each other would create entangled lists. It seems like you would more often want to create a disentangled ("shallow") copy rather than an entangled ("deep"?) copy.I suppose this is more a matter of curiosity regarding language architecture than anything else.

column8:
When the variable area is created, Python will first evaluate the expression on the right of the assignment operator, =. Whatever the value stored in the variables will be used. 
>>> base = 10
>>> height = 5
>>> area = base * height / 2 #At this point, base is 10 while height is 5
>>> area
25.0
>>> base = 15
>>> area
25.0
We still get 25.0 as the variable area only contains that value and not the actual expression base _height / 2. If we want to reflect the changes to area, we will have to do area = base * height / 2 again, this will take into account the changes we made to the variable base.

Unless you use Xcode for other purposes, you will not need it for this course. The main programme we will be using is IDLE, this comes bundled with your Python installation. It can be found inside Applications > Python 3.3
You can think of it that way, but functions and variables are different things.

column8: Well from my understanding, both the string as well as math functions are the same..functions. Since, string functions are most commonly used, they are loaded into the python runtime by default while other modules like os, math etc.. have to be explicitly loaded to be used. This ensures that python doesnt use inordinate amount of memory to load modules it wont use anyway.

column8: You have a fairly serious semantic error in your formulation of the quadratic formula. Ô_The answers that you are returning are in error. Consider the equation x**2 + 4 = 0. Ô_The roots are the imaginary numbers 0+2i and 0-2i. Ô_Your function returns the real numbers 4.0 and -4.0.The problem has to do with the order of precedence in evaluating power operator in your expression.

column2: Lectures / Week 1 / Python and Computer Memory
column8: values are stored in THE RAM (RANDOM ACCESS MEMORY)... the variables are simply pointing to the memory location of the ram where the value should be stored. Always remember, such things are stored in the ram and later retrieved from the ram if needed. Whenever you create a variable :let the variable in this case be foo:foo is actually pointing at a certain memory location in the ram. This memory location is entirely chosen by python. After initializing the variable foo with a value, the value is simply dumped into that memory location. Thus, the entire process is achieved in this way.

column8: you define complex numbers in python by appending `j` or `J` to the end of the imaginary number or using complex() function like below>>> variable1 = complex(3,4)>>> variable1(3+4j)>>> 1 + 0j(1+0j)>>> -23j(-0-23j)>>> 0j0j# and you can extract real and imaginary parts using real and imag methods.>>>variable1(3+4j)>>>variable1.real3.0>>> variable1.imag4.0absolute of complex number a+jb is square root of (a2+b2)(a^2+b^2) and thats what the abs will return >>> variable1 = complex(3,4)>>> variable1(3+4j)>>> absolute_value = (3**2 + 4**2)**0.5>>> absolute_value5.0>>> abs(variable1)5.0

you need not know what that particular functionÔ_ is beforehand, butÔ_ for a given function you should be able to understand how many arguments it takes and what it returns. from the help.
suppose lets see the below example:
lets see a function which we dont know;
( you can ask me how did i get to know the name of function which i dont know ?, well typeÔ_ dir(__builtins__) to get the builtin functions and types. )

here's a function in builtins called bin ( lets say we dont know anything about it) then running help on this function will yield us:
>>> help(bin)Help on built-in function bin in module builtins:bin(...)Ô_Ô_  bin(number) -> string    Return the binary representation of an integer.
as we can see from help `bin(num) -> string`Ô_ , we understand that it takes number as argument and return string type output.and from `Return the binary representation of an integer` , we understand the output is the binary representation of input number which must be integer ( see !)so from what we learned above, lets test how this function works :)>>> bin(1)'0b1'>>> bin(2)'0b10'>>> bin(2.5)Traceback (most recent call last):  File "<pyshell#61>", line 1, in     bin(2.5)TypeError: 'float' object cannot be interpreted as an integer>>> bin('23')Traceback (most recent call last):  File "", line 1, in     bin('23')TypeError: 'str' object cannot be interpreted as an integer>>> bin(-3)'-0b11'In the above tests, the bin is accepting only integers ( either positive or negatives)Ô_ and its returning a string of binary representation of input integer.

   Return the number of Celsius degrees equivalent to fahrenheit degrees.

column8:
EDITED
Additional Exercise for your Mind
Preface
You need to use Python 3 for this exercise. python 2 is not recommended.
Required Preparation
In order to complete this assignment, you'll probably need to have watched all the week 2 videos and also done the week 2 exercise. However, you can get a good start understanding the assignment. Understanding what a program should do almost always takes
    a significant amount of time, possibly as much as an hour or two.
Problem Domain: Joe's Vacation Trip!
We have a little friend Joe and he came to our city on a vacation.
he wants to see places in our city and so we ( us) went to nearby tourist center and surprised to see the tourist center full of Systems, running python scripts and no humans [ little exaggeration eh :P] .

A robot came to us, enquired and took us to a portal where the portal asked us how many places Joe want to see?
    

Joe replied four and selected the places place1, place2, place3 and place4.
    

Joe wanted to see the place1 first and place4 last and so the portal presented two functions time_to_go() and next_place() and We should help Joe to determine how much it will take him to complete his tour.
What to do
you have two functions (given below) available to you :Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_Ô_ time_to_go(place) and next_place(place)
    

the functions are given in the script here.Exercise Script 
    

you can see the functions purpose by loading the the Exercise Script given above and running help function on them .
    


    Now that you have two functions already made for you, you should create a function called trip_time() that takes no arguments and returns the time taken by our friend 'Joe' to visit four places place1, place2, place3 and place4.
    

trip_time() should return the time in hours:minutes:seconds format to complete four places place1, place2, place3 and place4.
you should first start with the place1 and end with place4.
    

time_to_go() will return the time in minutes ( little difficult to calculate seconds for you ! )
    

even though we are working with floats the time format should consist of only ints example:
    

if it took Joe 4 hours 32 minutes and 56 seconds then round_trip() should return 4:32:56 not 4.0:32.0:56.0
    

 Little Pre-requisite Help 
You could use two functions which i feel worth to explain here: there is a function called int()
excerpt from help(int) is given below:
int(x[, base]) -> integer
Convert a string or number to an integer, if possible. A floating point argument will be truncated towards zero (this does not include a string representation of a floating point number!) When converting a string, use the optional base. It is an error
to supply a base when converting a non-string.

examples of using int function are given below:
>>> int(12.23)12>>> int(12/3)4>>> int('124')124
there is another function called round()
help(round) returns following:
round(number[, ndigits]) -> number

Round a number to a given precision in decimal digits (default 0 digits). This returns an int when called with one argument, otherwise the same type as the number. ndigits may be negative.

examples of using round function are given below:
>>> round(23.234)23>>> round(23.2434,2)23.24>>> round(324/132,2)2.45

 Caution 

    You should not use print() function anywhere.
    You should Return the value in h:mm:ss format ( without any spaces)Ô_ only.
    You should use both the functions ( time_to_go(place) and next_place(place) ) at least once in your code even though you feel they are useless. ( the function next_place here is really useless but can't help it ).
        
    


you can see this thread https://class.coursera.org/programming1-002/forum/thread?thread_id=762 to know the diff between print and return

column8: Hello MichaelFirst of all, i presume that you won't mind if i took your program and refine it a little bit :POkay , lets make it even super simpler[ EDITED]def caesar_cipher(sentence, shift):    '''(str, int)-> str    Return encrypted message using a caesar cipher with given shift 'shift'     '''    encrypted = ''    for letter in sentence:        if( letter.isalpha()):            if(letter.islower()):                encrypted += chr(ord('a')+(ord(letter)-ord('a')+shift)%26)            else:                encrypted += chr(ord('A')+(ord(letter)-ord('A')+shift)%26)        else:            encrypted += letter    return encryptedThe Modified code above :accepts the punctuations marks, special characters and numbersaccepts the Capital or Small lettershopefully, doesn't crash most of the time as far as i know:)Ô_ Spirit of Open source ( Spirit of Python ) !!

column8: In C-like languages, programmer have to explicitly specify exactly how much space you need to store values (both in stack and heap) and make sure that you explicitly free space after it is not longer needed (heap space). And be extra careful not to stump over other values that might still be in use.I'm lazy and I really like that python interpreter will do thisÔ_hideous task for me. :)(I know... There is a penalty in execution speed... I don't care... :D)

column8:
I was under impression that inÔ_PythonesqueÔ_way types should not matter nor should it be stated in variable names, it should just work in it's intended context. I'm thinking in the sense that no matter what type I have (it may be a custom one)
if it has eg. a notion of items it should provideÔ_correspondingÔ_iterator methods and eg. "for x in y" construct will just work.
Like:

>>> text = "abcdfg"
>>> fruits = {'apple', 'orange', 'raspberry'}>>> some_primes = [2, 3, 5, 7]
>>> len(text)
6
>>> len(fruits)
3
>>> len(some_primes)
4
ItÔ_doesÔ_not care what type it was given - it just counts them.
Note, that I could beÔ_totallyÔ_wrong on this topic.

column8: I downloaded new IDLE themes from http://www.roguecode.net/2011/09/python-idle-themes.html and I use the Tango theme. Syntax highlighting makes it so much easier to work with the code!

I know we'll see this in week 2, but check how this all works in the Python Visualizer at http://pythontutor.com/visualize.html#code=x+%3D+2%0Ay+%3D+3%0Az+%3D+x+%2B+y%0A%0Ax+%3D+6%0Ay+%3D+7%0A&mode=display&cumulative=false&heapPrimitives=true&drawParentPointers=true&textReferences=false&showOnlyOutputs=false&py=3&curInstr=4 This website saved me from more than a few headaches! The trick is that we have to learn how Python works, not the way we'd like it to work. As said in the lecture, Python stores a reference to a memory address where a value is stored. If you look closer when x = 2gets re-assigned to x = 6you'll notice that the object 'int 2' (on the right-most column) disappears. The int 6 doesn't take its place in the same memory address, but is stored in a new memory address to which x now points to. The 'int 2' is simply gone (it's probably still in the same memory address, but nothing points to it). It's one of the main rules of Python I learned: you can't change an int in place (in the same memory address). I hope I made myself clear and didn't confuse you more!

Since I have a background in biology, when I read the description of the get_complementary_sequence function, I immediately thought of this as finding the reverse complement of a sequence. And it seemed to be true, because the auto-grader used the sequence 'GCTAGCTA' and expected it to return 'TAGCTAGC'. Like the name implies, first you take the complement of 'GCTAGCTA' (which is 'CGATCGAT') then reverse it to get 'TAGCTAGC'.So I was kind of confused when I saw that the example given in the handout stated that if we call this function with 'AT' as the argument, it returns 'TA'. However, using the same rule for the longer sequence, should not the function return 'AT' instead of 'TA'? Otherwise it is just returning the complement of 'AT'.

I think i have confused myself now.The question asks to return the number of minutes that have passed since midnight.For the get_minute(seconds) function, Ô_what I have done is take my input (seconds), and plug it into get_hours(seconds) method, then multiply it by 60 to get minutes. Ô_My get_hours(seconds) was marked as correct.I've also tested it several timesThese were my results:(3600 seconds is 1 hour since midnight, or 60 minutes)>>> get_minutes(3600)60(7200 seconds is 2 hours since midnight, which is 120 minutes)>>> get_minutes(7200)120(10800 is 3 hours since midnight, which is 180 seconds)>>> get_minutes(10800)180Any suggestions or advices would really be appreciated!Thanks!
get_minutes(3660) returns a value of 60. Ô_I used int division, rather than float.
oh opps your right!
I think i have been misunderstanding the question. Ô_I thought it wanted me to convert the seconds to minutes, then from minutes from midnight.I made the adjustments, and now works.Thanks!

I think the problem with a lot of this is not the syntax of the code, its more about figuring out what is needed to be done. Ô_For example, in the handout, It gave is a already defined function:def to_24_hour_clock(hours):Ô_ Ô_ Ô_ Ô_return hours % 24We know that % is a division that gives us a remainder, but a lot of people dont know how to use it, or when to use it. Ô_I also found that the description was hard to understand. Ô_I was actually fustrated because I been misunderstanding step 6maybe this will help you with the steps:step 2: Complete the code for function: seconds_differenceHere is the original description: Ô_The parameters are times in seconds. Return how manyÔ_secondsÔ_later the second time is than the first. Please note: inÔ_a1.py, we have provided the completed docstring for this function, including example function calls with the expected return values.This basically means return the amount of seconds that the second number is greater than the first number. Ô_Step 3:Ô_The parameters are times in seconds. Return how manyÔ_hoursÔ_later the second time is than the first. (Please note: inÔ_a1.py, we have provided the completed docstring for this function, including example function calls with the expected return values.)For this function, it takes in 2 different times in seconds. Ô_How many seconds is the second value greater than the first number? Ô_Then convert that number into hours. Ô_1 hour is 3600 seconds. Ô_step 4:Ô_The first parameter is a number of hours, the second parameter is a time in minutes (between 0 and 59, inclusive), and the third parameter is a time in seconds (between 0 and 59, inclusive). Return the combined time as aÔ_floatÔ_value. (Please note: inÔ_a1.py, we have provided the completed docstring for this function, including example function calls with the expected return values.)This one is more difficult. Ô_It gives us 3 numbers as parameters. Ô_the first paremeter is hours, second minutes, and third is seconds. They want us to spit out a number that is in decimal format. Ô_Here is a tip. Ô_Hours be left untouched. Ô_for minutes, you need to figure out, how to many seconds are in a minute, and for seconds, you need to figure out how many seconds is in 1 hour. Ô_Then add those numbers. Ô_Also, make sure you are using the "correct" division for float.step 5: They want 3 things. Ô_get_hours, get_minutes, get_seconds. Ô_All three functions wants us to return the amount of time that has a parameter of seconds. Ô_It wants us to convert the seconds to hours since midnight. Ô_Lets look at the first one, get_hours:We know that there is 3600 seconds in 1 hour. Ô_How do we convert seconds to hours? Ô_You need to divide some numbers together to get the converted amount in hours. Ô_Next, we have a already completed function:Ô_to_24_hour_clock(hours), that takes in the time in hours (hint hint). Ô_Something will just need to be inputted into that parameter to get the correct result.Now for get_minutes: it is similiar to the problem above, but it only wants the minutes portion of the time. Ô_For example, 4,007 seconds is 1 hour, 6 minutes, 47 seconds. get_minutes will return the minutes portion which is 6 minutes (reference: Allan Orrick).get_seconds is similiar to get_minutes, except it wants the seconds portion of the time. Ô_you will need to take the number in seconds, and do a very special division. Ô_Look at to_24_hour_clock function works. Ô_Then look at how many minutes are in 1 hour.for the last 2 functions:time_from_utc(utc_offset, time):it is asking:Ô_Return time at UTC+0, where utc_offset is the number of hours away fromÔ_UTC+0.Basically this means that they want the DIFFERENCE in time between between the offset from UTC 0. Ô_I think of it like this. Ô_Lets pretend we live in the middle of the world, and our time is set where everything starts. Ô_Our time zone is at 0. Ô_It never changes. Ô_Everyone else time zone is derived from us. Ô_Japan is 2 hours ahead from us. Ô_If it is currently 11:00 at our time zone, japan must be 13:00 their time. Ô_How much time has passed between us?The second function:time_from_utc(utc_offset, time). Ô_It says:Ô_The first parameter is a UTC offset specifying a time zone and the second parameter is a time in time zone UTC+0. Return the equivalent time in the time zone specified byÔ_utc_offset.Ô_Using the example above. Ô_Japan is +2 hours ahead of us. Ô_and we are 14:00 time. Ô_What should the time in japan be?Hopefully this will help you. Ô_Please keep trying!

It looks like your function doesn't have a return statement. Ô_Your return statement should be in a function. Ô_A return statement does 2 things:1) it ends the function2) It allows the function to spit out a data.It should look something like this:def myFunction(nun1, num2):Ô_ Ô_ Ô_ return num1 + num2>>> myFunction(100, 200)>>> 300In this example, myFunction takes in 2 numbers of 100, and 200. Then it calculates the return statement that was defined in the function, and spits it back out. Ô_A reason why we would use a return statement is because we can assign a function to a variable. Ô_For example:>>> myNumers = myFunction(100, 200)in that example, the function will kick off, returning a value of 300, and assigns 300 to myNumbers variable.Also note, in python, indentation is important. Ô_By having your code indented, it lets python know that statement is part of the function.

You are soo close!You have the right formula! Ô_For your function get_hours, we know that to_24_hour_clock(hours) already does:Ô_hours % 24. Ô_And you have already did the caculation for converting seconds to hours.Do you see something that is unnecessary in your get_hours function?

It may just be me and my poor understanding of English, but the phrasing
 of this question had me confused for a long time so I'm throwing this 
out there in case it helps anyone. "Select the code fragment(s) that 
prints the average of all passing 
grade(s). The printed value should be 0.0 if neither grade is a passing 
grade, the passing grade if exactly one grade is a passing grade,
 and 
the average of the two grades if both are passing grades."

What I understood from this was that if only one of the two gradesÔ_ was a
 passing grade, the printed value should be 50 (the minimum passing 
grade!). I obviously couldn't find a right answer, and it's only later I
 realized that what was meant was that the printed value should be the 
actual value of the grade that is higher than 50.

I think Anon is right, try different indentation for the return statement (same level as for).

You do have to change it slightly - you're writing a whole string of characters now, not just one. But think about what you want your loop to work like: it's supposed to go over every character in the sequence and, depending on which of the 4 characters it stumbles on, add its counterpart to the output string.
I would imagine that all code used in such ways would be excessively tested in flight simulators before being approved for actual use.

column8: I'm a complete beginner. My university offered an intro into Java programming course, but I went a few times and everything the professor said/did went right over my head, so in the end I chose another module. I've regretted it a little, so I wanted to give programming another go.I signed up because I often find that I could do my work better if I could program. I deal with lots of data and while we have all the fancy toys for analysing, sometimes I'm finding myself stuck with an Excel sheet and a bunch of unsorted data. I'm hoping that by learning to program I will be able to write little useful programs for automatically sorting that data, sometimes between different documents.I also have been thinking about a project, also for work. We have huge amounts of documents, personal templates and research papers in our intranet, but often people work at the same thing someone else already did simply because they don't know that those documents exist. So I've been thinking about making some sort of platform where people could update their projects, tag them according to the type, topic etc. and link that post to the actual document... Pretty sure I won't manage that after this one class, but it's a start, or so I hope. :)

To close the triple-quoted string, you used commas (,,,) - you need to use quote marks, same as what you opened the string with ('''). I think python thinks the string is still open (ie you haven't closed it) and in fact your return statement (return fahrenheit - 32 * 5 / 9) is being interpreted as part of a still open string!Replace the ,,, with ''' and everything should be okay.Also, you haven't closed the brackets in the type contract, but as this is part of the string it doesn't affect the running of the function.
column13: What's wrong with my Function design recipe

column8: When time // 3600 is being evaluated, you're getting the hours part, but what you need is theÔ_remainderÔ_to get the minutes and seconds (maybe try time % 3600 - this will then spit out a number which you would then perform an operation on to get minutes). Similarly for the remaining seconds...I hope this makes some sense!

Hey Nick,The design recipe is a set of instructions to build a complete function, not just what's between the header and code body (ie. header and code body are aÔ_partÔ_of the total design recipe):ExamplesWhat should your function do?Type a couple of example calls.Pick a name (often a verb or verb phrase): What is a short answer to "What does your function do"?Type ContractWhat are the parameter types?What type of value is returned?HeaderPick meaningful parameter names.DescriptionMention every parameter in your description.Describe the return value.BodyWrite the body of your function.TestRun the examples.Tim

This is what PEMDAS Stands for:

P
 Parentheses first 

E
 Exponents (ie Powers and Square Roots, etc.) 

MD
 Multiplication and  Division (left-to-right) 

AS
 Addition and Subtraction (left-to-right)

Nasharuddin bin Jbin.....Windows is a funny little untolerant monster.....lets start from scratch....These steps may be considered a little elementary for some, but its a sure fire way of making sure you get the program and install it.1.Ô_ lets look atÔ_your securitys setting first.2. start up your control panel (you do this by clicking on the windows task bar, left click on the windows logo, and then left click on control panel [you'll see it on the right side of program GUI].3. I'm assuming you have Windows 7, but its the same in windows XP, not sure of what it looks like in WIndows 8,Ô_ I'm not familiar with Windows 8, (maybe someone else can guide you to the control panel in Windows 8)4. Look for "System and Security" < left click > (new screen pops up)5. IN the new screen -look for "windows firewall" -Ô_ (remember these steps, because your probably going to have to return to undo the change your about to make)6. <left click> on Allow a program through Windows firewall7. In the list that pops up, (scroll down till you find Python(if it is in there, then make sure that the little box is checked on (on the left side), then also in the column (home/work(private) make sure its checked off.8. if it isn't there, then your security system isn't considering Python a treat, or you haven't installed it yet.9. If you had to click to put a check on anything, then exit the window by clicking on OK at the bottom of the window.10. if you didn't have to make a change, then click on CANCEL at the bottom of the window.11. OK, now lets download the program. (go to the link given to you by the class instructor)12. since your an x86 system, you will be downloading the x86 version of Python....but make sure you save it to yourdrive....(when you click on the download, a bar at the bottom of your screen comes up asking you to "run" or "save as" , I would recommend to "save as".Ô_ click on "save as".13. before you click on OK, make sure you see where the file will be saved too.Ô_ You can move the file folders and click on the folders to save the (downloading file) to anywhere you want.Ô_ Just remember where you save it.14.Ô_ Depending on your internet speed, it will then give you a progress percentage reading on that bottom bar, in the main screen. ONce its downloaded it will ask you if you want to open it, or view the download (I always select "view the download")Ô_ 15....a new window should had opened up if you clicked on view the download.16.Ô_ a pull down window next to the name of the file you just downloaded gives you the option to open the containing folder. (open the containing folder)17. here is where it now gets tricky.18.Ô_put your cursor over the file in that folder, where it is just waiting for you to click on.19. (RIGHT CLICK <<<<<<<(note that its a right side button, not the one you always click,, the other one)20. select run as administrator21, now let it do its thing.22. follow the prompts, and you should be ok.Hope this helps, if not, let me know and I'll help you.David

Hi Kira.Ô_ As Wayne says, the square brackets indicate an optional argument.Ô_ If you type in help(round) it will say that it defaults to 0, so if you leave it out then it rounds to zero decimal places.Ô_ In your exampleÔ_Ô_Ô_ round(54.6665)will give the answer 55.Ô_ However if you wanted it to round to two decimal places you would typeÔ_Ô_ round (54.6665, 2)which gives the answer 54.67In your own example you would get the answer 54.6665, since the number you specified only has 4 decimal places and you have asked for the number to 5 decimal places, so it's the same number.

column8: Chinmay,writing code in a console, is mainly like writing code in the windows notepad.You see just some text, without colour, without any kind of "help". And then, you've tosave your "text" (your program) and run it from a command line.If you use IDLE, you see coloured text that helps you recognizing what you're writing(a function, a number, a variable etc), you have auto-completion and oftenthe IDLE says you if you're doing some errors before the compilation and the run.It is very very easier to write a program in an IDE instead that in a command line!

Dear Anon,Thanks your response. I have successfully submitted my assignment. The system accepted the submission of each additional step to the a1.py file.Now I can take a deep sigh of relief.

Hi Ajayi,Instead of editing the a1.py file, I followed the sample provided and created my own a1.py file. After completing the body (which is 'return .......') for Step 2, I tested the example calls for the expected results using the Python Shell. Then I submit my a1.py file. It should show 5 pts. I submitted my a1.py file every time I finished and tested a Step. You will find that the points keep increasing. The get_minutes and get_seconds functions are a bit tricky. I had error the first time because I was using the minus sign. Someone in the discussion forum suggested using % and it worked.Although it's tedious, I find that I learn better by typing out each function. Hope this helps.Ô_

Hi Saral,The body for to_24_hour_clock function has already been provided: return hours % 24. The to_24_hour_clock function is to show you how to use % to get rid of the 24 hours as seen in the first two example calls for (24) and (48), both returning 0. The use of % comes in useful when you write the body for get_minutes and get_seconds function.Hope this helps.

column2: Lectures / Week 1 / Getting Started: Installing Python
column8: So I thought I'd post this on the off chance that it's helpful to someone else who's just starting out with this course using Linux Mint (or similar Linux Build). With the newest Linux Mint version, "Olivia" 15 KDE, IDLE is an independent install through the Software Manager. However, the version you get through the Software Manager runs on the default version of Python, which at the moment is 2.7.4. So you'd be running a 2.x shell instead of a 3.x.So the simplest solution here is opening the Konsole (terminal) and typing the following (don't bother typing the bold stuff. It's just what Konsole shows):USER@COMPUTER:~ > sudo apt-get install idle3Hit enter and it will ask you for the admin password for the system and then another enter will run it. Konsole will pull down the necessary information and then ask you to approve installation of any dependencies (other programs IDLE 3 needs). You'll get a [Y/n]? statement. Enter Y and enter again. It will finish installing on its own after that point and will eventually show the USER@COMPUTER:~ > line again. You'll be able to find the program under Applications > Development > IDLE 3 in the main menu.As a side note, these steps might be different for people on different versions of Linux. I haven't used many of them personally. Just Mint. If it doesn't work for you, I'd look up to see what install command your Linux build will accept.Anyway. Just thought that might help one or two people. Good luck. :D

column2: Lectures / Week 1 / Python as a Calculator
column8: aha, I might get the idea now. Here is my understanding. Feel free to correct me if this is not the correct understanding: Since the first bit of 4 is 1 while the first bit of 2 is Ô_0, " ^ " results "1" in the position of first bit. Then it begin to compare the second bit, which is 0 vs 1, resulting "1" again. The last bit comparison is 0 vs 0, and the result is 0. Ô_So the final results is 110. Then 110 is converted into 6 as a binary number.

column8: Michael gives a good example. Let's say, grade1 and grade2 are both greater than 50, then for the first if statement, we get num_passed to be 2. But the other lower two if statements are not nested into the first one, they are separated, which means they have to be executed step by step whether or not the first if statement is true. So for the example Michael takes, we'll get 1 in the console even if result 2 is expected.Ô_

But that folder might not be in your PATH system variable, ie. where windows look for executables.You can look online to see how to change your path, a good set of instructions I found is here http://geekswithblogs.net/renso/archive/2009/10/21/how-to-set-the-windows-path-in-windows-7.aspx

column8:
A parameter is something that you specify in your function declaration.An argument is anÔ_specificÔ_value that is passed to a parameter in a function call.In other words, an example in the Calculus realm may help. Suppose you define a function like this: f(x)=2x+1.Here the "x" in "f(x)" is the parameter to the function.Now suppose you want to evaluate that function in x=1 --> f(1)=2*1+1=3That "1" in "f(1)" is an argument to the function.In Python, when you define a function, say def myFunction (hi)Ô_ Ô_ print hi;
return;Here, "hi" in "myFunction (hi)" is a parameter.When you call the function you will do something like this: myFunction ("My name is John Doe")Here "My name is John Doe" is an argument. And you will get that message in the screen.Hope it helps.

I think that being a Programmer is not so much about knowing your Maths, or your code; it's a way of thinking (that's not to say the former are unimportant). There are plenty of tools and resources to help us with our mathematics, IDEs now complete our code for us, provide us with suggestions for function calls, etc. But what all those tools cannot give us is the way we think, the way we approach the problem before us. To be a Programmer, you need to be able to correctly identify the problem before you, to see it in a structured way, and to be able to break it down into logical pieces.
